title: Snow warnings lifted after winter weather wreaks havoc on B.C.’s South Coast Vancouver
text:
The snow warnings for Metro Vancouver have been lifted, but not before the weather wreaked havoc once again in B.C.’s South Coast.
Between 10 and 20 centimetres of snow fell Friday throughout Metro Vancouver on Friday, causing mayhem on the region’s roads.
Environment Canada cancelled the special weather statement Saturday morning, although several centimetres of wet flurries are forecasted for the afternoon.
The City of Vancouver said they prepared for the snowfall for days, and major routes were the priority. Residents are being urged to clear their sidewalks, or call the Snow Angel program if assistance is needed.
The snowfall also cut power to approximately 23,000 homes in the Lower Mainland, Gulf Islands, Sunshine Coast, and North Vancouver Island regions.
TransLink reported delays on Friday, noting this was expected to continue while winter weather lasted and customers should allow for extra travel time. HandyDART was operating on essential services only, and some SkyTrain delays were reported on Expo and Millenium Lines.
The Alex Fraser Bridge northbound was closed Saturday afternoon, according to DriveBC.
#BCHWY91 #AlexFraserBridge NB is going to be CLOSED due to winter conditions. Please use alternate route.
— Drive BC (@DriveBC) February 4, 2017 The 28th annual Pacific Road Runners First Half Marathon was supposed to be held on Sunday along Stanley Park’s seawall, but was cancelled due to snowy weather.
“It is with deep disappointment that Pacific Road Runners has made the decision to cancel this year’s race due to the weather,” Race Director Terry Bushnell said in a Facebook statement.
“Two of our committee members inspected the seawall early this morning and reported back. It was obvious that it makes no sense to continue with the race.”
This was the first time in the race’s 28-year history that the event was cancelled.
Snowfall warnings are still in effect for the Fraser Valley, Whistler, How Sound, and Inland Vancouver Island.
